article.title: The US economy has been 'more than fine' without your student debt

news.lede: Student-loan payments have been on pause for nearly two years, with a recent extension through May 1. There's controversy over the merits of broad relief, with some arguing it's bad for the economy. But experts told Insider it gave borrowers more financial flexibility, allowing for the pursuit of better jobs.
Look beyond flagships, and you'll see that privatization has had devastating consequences for racial and social equity.

article.title: Elite private universities got much wealthier while most schools fell behind. My research found out why.

news.lede: Insiders helped out insiders, and the rich got richer

article.title: Student debt "feels like quicksand." Is loan forgiveness the answer?

news.lede: 42.9 million Americans had federal student loans as of last year, according to the National Student Loan Data System. Meanwhile, Federal Reserve Board statistics show outstanding student loans overall have swelled to $1.7 trillion, surpassing the nation's auto loans and credit card debt.

article.title: Op-Ed: Is it possible to fix the UC’s system of haves and have-nots?

news.lede: Black and Latinx students are entering college at a far higher rate than ever before, but higher education in America remains racially divided and unequal. And California may well stand at the epicenter of that transformation.

article.title: Exclusive: These for-profit colleges could reap up to $1 billion in federal bailout money

news.lede: Some eligible schools have been accused of fraud and misuse of federal student aid

article.title: Broke: the racial consequences of underfunding public universities

news.lede: Q&A: Victor Ray with authors Laura Hamilton and Kelly Nielsen

article.title: Broke: The Racial Consequences of Underfunding Public Universities

news.lede: The two editors and two of the contributing authors to the new book Critical Praxis in Authors Laura Hamilton and Kelly Nielsen discuss their book Broke: The Racial Consequences of Underfunding Public Universities. This conversation explores new universities, racial justice, austerity administration, tolerable suboptimization, and the implications for students, faculty and staff, and democracy.

article.title: Podcast Transcript: Is the University of California Broke?

news.lede: Host Daniel Barwick interviews authors Laura Hamilton and Kelly Nielsen, who argue on the podcast that California has made decisions about UC that have impoverished campuses in a number of ways, limited access, and created segregation.
We discuss the financialization of higher education with Charlie Eaton (UC Merced).
Spurred by cheap loans and investors desperate to boost returns, buyout firms roam every corner of the corporate world.

article.title: Warren Probes Apollo and KKR on Backing For-Profit Colleges

news.lede: The Massachusetts Democrat has targeted six private-equity firms amid growing congressional scrutiny of the industry

article.title: How Elite Colleges Hide THeir Cash

news.lede: It’s an increasingly bipartisan view that elite private colleges are islands of wealth. And there’s good reason for that: It’s true.

article.title: Endowments Boom as Colleges Bury Earnings Overseas

news.lede: American universities are using offshore strategies to swell their coffers, skirt taxes and obscure investments that could spark campus protests.

article.title: These states give more grant aid to college students in need than the feds

news.lede: California, Wyoming and New Jersey provide more aid to low-income college students than the largest federal grant program does, new research shows, but most states give far less.
